title: CMK-3 Carbon Nanopipes Arrangement Synthesized with Pectin Extracted from Golden Delicious Apple
content: Mesoporous materials have been widely studied due to their applications mainly as adsorbents and catalysts. The CMK-3 material is a mesoporous carbon synthesized using a silica SBA-15 as a hard template and sucrose as a carbon source [1]. The carbon nanopipes arrangement is an inverse replica of the SBA-15 cylindrical mesopores. Their hierarchical porosity refers to the slit micropores of carbon and the mesoporous given by the template [2], which provides the carbon material with a variety of characteristics like strength and stability against cyclic and thermal treatments [3]. The most common carbon precursors for CMK-3 synthesis are sucrose, furfuryl alcohol, glucose, phenolic resins, acetonitrile, and others [4]. This project aims to propose a new, economical, and environmentally friendly carbon source (pectin from Golden Delicious apple) to improve the CMK-3 synthesis method and elucidate their nanopipes arrangement employing microscopy techniques. The SBA-15 template was synthesized following the procedure described in Quiroz et al., 2023 [1] for a typical synthesis procedure. For the CMK-3-pectin carbon synthesis, the methodology reported by Ryoo, 2000 [2] was modified substantially for the precursor source and the temperature ramps. Briefly, the carbon source was pectin, extracted from Golden Delicious Apples following the acid hydrolysis method described by Rojas-Candelas et al, 2022 in a previous report [5]. Then, 1 g of silica template was mixed with 2.3 g of pectin and 10 ml of diluted H2SO4; the mixture was dehydrated at 363 K followed by the increase of temperature to 453 K, both for 4 hours. After that, the pyrolysis step at 700Â°C and the remotion of the silica template with hydrofluoric acid were carried out. Finally, the SBA-15 and CMK-3-pectin from apple were observed using a scanning electron microscope (Hitachi, SU3500 I, Santa Clara, CA, USA) at 5.0 kV. The micrographs of SBA and CMK-3-pectin from apple were obtained by a transmission electron microscope (field emission electron microscope JEM-2010F, USA). All images were analyzed using Digital Micrograph software (v. 3.7.1, Gatan Software Team, USA).
